p: RSV also is one of the most common viral causes of serious lower respiratory tract illness in the elderly, especially in institutionalized subjects [ 17]. Exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are frequently associated with RSV infection [ 18, 19]. The elderly do not exhibit a remarkably diminished level of antibodies to RSV [ 20]. Decreased levels of T cell memory in the elderly and specifically in patients with (COPD) may contribute to the increased susceptibility to RSV infection in these populations [ 21]. Many think of influenza virus as the principal viral respiratory pathogen in this population, but in a hospitalized cohort, influenza A virus and RSV infection resulted in similar mortality, lengths of stay, and rates of use of intensive care [ 17]. RSV infection accounted for over 10 % of hospitalizations for pneumonia.
